title: Is there any connection between research and development and product life cycle management? - Quora

response.answer_text: Research and development (R&D, R+D, or R’n’D), known in Europe as research and technological development (RTD), refers to innovative activities undertaken by corporations or governments in developing new services or products, or improving existing services or products. Research and development constitutes the first stage of development of a potential new service or the production process. R&D activities differ from institution to institution, with two primary models of an R&D department either staffed by engineers and tasked with directly developing new products, or staffed with industrial scientists and tasked with applied research in scientific or technological fields, which may facilitate future product development. R&D differs from the vast majority of corporate activities in that it is not intended to yield immediate profit, and generally carries greater risk and an uncertain return on investment. However R&D is crucial for acquiring larger shares of the market through the marketisation of new products.

There are a lot of connections as depicted here in this product management lifecycle framework. First, the product manager defines the product strategy including what problems are being solved for which persona customers and then the rest. Second it’s handed off to research and development for the construction of the solution…the product. Third, the product (or intangible product called as “service”) is brought to market and provides marketing/sales support by the product marketing manager.
